column1: One of the main features that Blocks specialises in is reviews. This issue contains 3, which is sub-par compared to the other issues. The set is judged on minifigures, price, build and playability just to name a few, resulting in a score out of 100.

It provides in-depth pictures of each stage of the finished model but highlights the size and, not lack of playability, but the fact that it is difficult to play with and not knock off a dozen pieces. It also shows some of the rooms left almost bare, encouraging mods (more on that later).&nbsp

column1: The next build article is a Steampunk Batman Mech. The clue is in the name really. Not much else to say.
The last build article is a mod. This highlights 75192 Millennium Falcon'
column2: s interior space. It is Part 1 of a series spread across issues. This part focuses on the crew quarters and shows an almost step-by-step guide on how to build 3 beds in the on-screen style, a swivel chair and a feature control wall.&nbsp

column1: Many issues cover a video game and this is no exception. This time, it is LEGO Marvel Super Heroes 2. It shows some scenes from the video game and how it performs compared to the last one.
I recommend this issue to Star Wars fans (the Millennium Falcon), City fans (Winter Village) and DC fans (steampunk batman and the Joker Manor).

I hope this review gave you some insight of what you get in a Blocks magazine issue. You can order past issues in digital form or find recent ones on the Blocks website blocksmag.com. The aim was to give you some information but leave you itching for more and I hope I succeeded. Please be aware that Blocks is a British establishment and it costs a lot more per issue anywhere else in the world, particularly the US. Thanks for reading and please support future Blocks issues to keep the magazine going!
